Description: Reddish brown glazed composition amuletic figure, rather crudely executed, in the form of an animal (?), possibly a seated cat, transversely pierced for suspension.
Findspot: Found/Acquired: Tell Dafana, North-west ptolemaic mound ? (?)
Dimensions: Height: 0.84 centimetres (approx. as set into mount)
Curator's comments: Provenance not specified in the Museum register, but probably from Tell Dafana according to the context of the item in the list, and similarity in shape and material with other amulets from the site Probably one of the "much smaller and ruder" "glazed pottery amulets of late work, probably late Ptolemaic", from the North-west mound, maybe one of the "6 cats", mentioned by W.M.F. Petrie, Tanis ii, Nebesheh and Defenneh, p. 79 § 79. See the similar London, BM, EA 20676, 20677, 20678, 20679, 20680 and possibly 20685.
Bibliographic references: Petrie 1888 / Tanis. Part II. Nebesheh (Am) and Defenneh (Tahpanhes) (p. 79 § 79) (?)
Leclère and Spencer 2014 / Tell Dafana Reconsidered: The Archaeology of an Egyptian Frontier Town (p.40, p.45, p.62, p.63, p.64, p.180, pl.22)
